results.title: Bucking Republican Trend, Indiana Governor Vetoes Transgender Sports Bill
results.abstract: Gov. Eric Holcomb nixed legislation that would have blocked transgender girls from playing school sports. Eleven states have enacted similar bills.

results.title: School Video Shows Off-Duty Officer Putting His Knee on a Girl’s Neck
results.abstract: The officer, a member of the Kenosha Police Department in Wisconsin, has resigned from his school security job.

multimedia.caption: In this still image from a video, Shawn Guetschow, working off-duty as a security guard at Lincoln Middle School, holds a student to the floor and puts his knee on her neck after a fight between her and another student in the cafeteria.

results.title: ‘We Can’t Endure This’: Surge in U.S. Shootings Shows No Sign of Easing
results.abstract: A deadly weekend was an ominous harbinger for the summer months ahead, which is typically America’s most violent time.
results.byline: By Tim Arango and Troy Closson

multimedia.caption: A shell casing remains in a parking lot after a shooting in Dumas, Arkansas. Researchers estimate that there are at least 15 million more guns in circulation than there would have been due to a purchasing increase in the U.S.

results.abstract: Senators will get their final shot at questioning the Supreme Court nominee, but it is unclear whether any new ground will be broken.

results.title: Project Veritas Says Justice Dept. Secretly Seized Its Emails
results.abstract: In a court filing, the conservative group assailed prosecutors for concealing the action in a proceeding from the investigation of how it acquired Ashley Biden’s diary.
results.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Adam Goldman

multimedia.caption: James O’Keefe, the founder of Project Veritas, in Orlando, Fla., in February. Prosecutors have disputed the group’s claims that it is entitled to First Amendment protections in the investigation into how it acquired Ashley Biden’s diary.

James O’Keefe, the founder of Project Veritas, in Orlando, Fla., in February. Prosecutors have disputed the group’s claims that it is entitled to First Amendment protections in the investigation into how it acquired Ashley Biden’s diary.

results.title: Pledging to ‘Stay in My Lane,’ Jackson Defends Her Record
results.abstract: As Republicans suggested she was soft on crime, particularly when it came to child sexual abuse, and an extremist on matters of race, the Supreme Court nominee pushed back.
results.byline: By Carl Hulse and Katie Rogers

multimedia.caption: “I am acutely aware that as a judge in our system, I have limited power and I am trying in every case to stay in my lane,” Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson said on Tuesday.
“I am acutely aware that as a judge in our system, I have limited power and I am trying in every case to stay in my lane,” Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson said on Tuesday.
“I am acutely aware that as a judge in our system, I have limited power and I am trying in every case to stay in my lane,” Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson said on Tuesday.

results.title: Rival Sept. 11 Victims Near Potential Deal to Divide Afghan Central Bank Assets
results.abstract: But another group opposes it. A court has not yet decided whether $3.5 billion in Afghan central bank funds can be used to pay Taliban debts.

results.title: Utah Governor Vetoes Transgender-Athlete Bill

results.title: Ukraine War and Pandemic Force Nations to Retreat From Globalization
results.abstract: Conflicts among the U.S., Russia and China — and endless Covid-19 outbreaks — strain the interdependent economy and Western ideas of post-Cold War stability.

results.title: Victor Fazio, Longtime Democratic Leader in the House, Dies at 79
results.abstract: Known for his ability to work across the aisle, he represented the Sacramento area from 1979 to 1999 and rose to become chairman of the House Democratic caucus.

multimedia.caption: The California Democrat Victor Fazio with President Bill Clinton in 1997 at the dedication of the Vic Fazio Yolo Wildlife Area. Mr. Fazio, who served 20 years in Congress, had lobbied for the funds to protect 3,700 acres of wetlands west of Sacramento as a refuge.
multimedia.copyright: Hector Amezcua/The Sacramento Bee, via Associated Press

multimedia.copyright: Hector Amezcua/The Sacramento Bee, via Associated Press

results.title: Here’s the context behind what Judge Jackson wrote about war crimes.
results.abstract: Two Republicans asserted during the second day of confirmation hearings on Tuesday that Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson had called former Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld and former President George W. Bush “war criminals.” But she never used that phrase.
results.byline: By Charlie Savage, Carol Rosenberg and Linda Qiu
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
